D4A.one_liner: The D4A was a revolutionary desktop computer from 1963, known as the 'calculator in a cigar box'.

questions.text: Looking at this old computer, does it feel nostalgic, primitive, or impressive to you?
What struck you most about it—its size, the buttons, or its age?
What would help you understand its history better?

Asan.AI.one_liner: Asan.AI lets you play with a neural network in the browser to see how machines learn without complex math.

questions.text: Did experimenting with the AI model feel empowering, confusing, or too simple?
What part was most clear—the visuals, the controls, or the results?
If you could change one thing about this interface, what would it be?

Swarming bacteria.one_liner: This simulation shows how bacteria move collectively in 'active liquids' to flow better.

questions.text: Watching the bacteria swarm, did it feel mesmerizing, gross, or just scientific?
What caught your eye—the patterns, the speed, or the chaos?
What would make this simulation more engaging for you?

Chatbot.one_liner: This exhibit questions whether AI is truly 'smart' or just predicting the next word based on patterns.

questions.text: Did the AI's answers feel smart, robotic, or surprisingly human?
What gave it away—the voice, the phrasing, or the logic?
What would make talking to this bot feel more natural?

Circuit Flowfields.one_liner: This artwork visualizes the massive speed and colored data processes running through Dresden's supercomputers.

questions.text: Did the data visualization feel chaotic, beautiful, or overwhelming?
Was it the colors, the speed, or the scale that made you feel that way?
What would help you understand the data behind the art better?

Complex calculations.one_liner: This exhibit simulates biological processes to show how cells and tissues maintain their shape.

questions.text: Did these biological simulations seem abstract or clear to you?
What part was hardest to grasp—the shapes, the movement, or the explanation?
How could we explain the math behind this biology better?

Complexity Explorables.one_liner: These interactive models let you control swarm behavior and patterns using simple sliders.

questions.text: Did playing with the parameters feel powerful, confusing, or fun?
Which control or slider had the most surprising effect?
What other system or pattern would you like to control here?

Data traces.one_liner: Data Traces uses LiDAR to track your path through the exhibition and build a profile of your interests.

questions.text: Seeing your own movement profile, did you feel exposed, impressed, or indifferent?
Was the profile accurate about what you liked?
What would make this tracking data easier to understand?

Dresden mapping.one_liner: This digital twin of Dresden simulates flood events and urban infrastructure planning.

questions.text: Did seeing the flood simulation feel alarming, informative, or distant?
Did you recognize specific places, or was it the water flow that stood out?
What other city scenario would you like to see simulated?

Faces.one_liner: Faces explores how facial data can be detected, tracked, and interpreted by systems.

questions.text: Did Faces feel more playful or unsettling to you?
What detail triggered that feeling—movement, eyes, tracking, or something else?
What would make the message of Faces clearer or more comfortable?

Film Forms.one_liner: Film Forms transforms iconic movie scripts into 3D sculptures using sentiment analysis data.

questions.text: Did the shape of the movie scripts feel abstract, beautiful, or confusing?
Could you see the connection between the movie story and the shape?
What other movie would you like to see turned into a shape?

Hyperuniformity.one_liner: Hyperuniformity is a state of matter between crystal order and liquid disorder.

questions.text: Did the patterns look orderly, random, or somewhere in between?
What did the visual pattern remind you of in the real world?
How could we explain this complex physics concept better?

Magic Mirror.one_liner: The Magic Mirror uses deep learning to let you virtually try on clothes by describing them.

questions.text: Was the virtual try-on fun, awkward, or futuristic?
Did the clothes match what you described, or was the AI confused?
What would make the mirror feel more like a real changing room?

Mathematical models.one_liner: These historical models represent complex equations and functions as physical objects.

questions.text: Do these physical models make math feel more accessible or still dry?
Does seeing the equation as a shape help you understand it?
How could we bring these static models to life?

Retro Reboot.one_liner: Retro Reboot lets you punch code onto tape strips to make music or graphics, just like early computers.

questions.text: Did punching the code feel like hard work, fun, or creative?
Did you enjoy the physical feeling of 'programming' by hand?
What would make the result of your punched tape clearer?

Sandbox.one_liner: Sandbox lets visitors explore data ideas through hands-on interaction with sand.

questions.text: Quick check: how did the Sandbox feel overall—curious, playful, confusing, or unsettling?
What exactly caused that feeling—was it the touch, the visuals, or the explanation?
If you could change one thing in Sandbox to improve it, what would it be?

Seamless pattern.one_liner: This T-shirt design uses math to ensure the pattern continues perfectly across the seams.

questions.text: Is the seamless design something you noticed immediately, or did it feel subtle?
Does knowing the math behind the T-shirt make it more interesting?
What other object would you like to see with this seamless math?

Server cabinet.one_liner: The Server Cabinet shows the loud, hot physical reality of where data lives.

questions.text: Did the server cabinet feel loud, impressive, or boring?
What surprised you most—the noise, the heat, or the lights?
What would help you understand what these machines are actually doing?

Server kit.one_liner: Server Kit lets you use blocks to physically build and configure a high-performance server.

questions.text: Did building the server with blocks feel like a puzzle, a lesson, or a game?
Did you understand what each block represented?
What would make the connection to real computer hardware clearer?

Time travel.one_liner: Time Travel explores the history of computer science in Dresden from the 1940s to the 1960s.

questions.text: Did the local history of computers feel relevant, surprising, or a bit dry?
Which decade or machine was the most interesting to read about?
How could we make this history feel more alive?

Traces.one_liner: Traces visualizes where visitors have been in the exhibition using LiDAR scans.

questions.text: Seeing the visitor paths, did you feel part of a swarm or observed?
Could you identify your own movement in the visualization?
What other data about the visitors would be interesting to see?

VR experience.one_liner: The VR experience immerses you in a data-driven environment to explore patterns and perception.

questions.text: How comfortable was the VR experience—great, okay, or dizzy?
What part stood out most—visuals, motion, story, or interaction?
One improvement for VR—what would make it better?
